metadata.title: Preparation and activity of Cu/ZnO-CNTs nano-catalyst on steam reforming of methanol

Fig. 1 FTIR spectra of carbon nano-tubes: (a) without chemical pre-treatment and (b) with chemical pre-treatment. Fig. 2 TGA spectra of carbon nano-tubes: (a) with chemical pre-treatment and (b) without chemical pre-treatment; preparation conditions: 15wt% Cu/CNTs catalysts, chemical pre-treatment with 27.7cm3 of 0.01M Cu(NO3)2·3H2O solution, 10/1 of molar ratio of formaldehyde to copper nitrate, 37% formaldehyde. Fig. 3 TEM micrographs of Cu-CNTs: (a) without ethanol, (b) CNT without chemical pre-treatment and (c) addition of ethanol and CNT with chemical pre-treatment. Fig. 4 XRD analysis of 23wt% Cu/ZnO-CNTs catalysts: (▾) CNT, (▿) CuO, (♦) ZnO and (●) Cu. Fig. 5 Effect of reaction temperature on gas product distribution. Reaction conditions: 0.2g of 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs catalyst, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric flow rate of mixed water and methanol liquid=7cm3/h, molar ratio of water to methanol=1.5, temperature 200–400°C, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min: (♦) methanol, (■) hydrogen, (▴) carbon monoxide and (×) carbon dioxide. Fig. 6 Effect of molar ratio of water to methanol in feed on hydrogen production. Reaction conditions: 0.2g of 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric flow rate of mixed water and methanol liquid=7cm3/h, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min; temperature (°C): (♦) 200, (■) 240, (▴) 280, (×) 320, (*) 360 and (●) 400. Fig. 7 Effect of reaction temperature on selectivity of CO2. Reaction conditions: 0.2g of 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs catalyst, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric flow rate of mixed water and methanol liquid=7cm3/h, temperature: 200–400°C, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min; molar ratio of water to methanol: (♦) 2.5, (■) 1.8, (▴) 1.5, (×) 1.3, (*) 1.1, (●) 0.8 and (+) 0.5. Fig. 8 Effect of total metal loading of catalyst on hydrogen production. Reaction conditions: 0.2g of Cu80ZnO20-CNTs, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric flow rate of mixed water and methanol liquid=7cm3/h, molar ratio of water to methanol in feed=1.5, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min; temperature (°C): (♦) 200, (■) 240, (▴) 280, (×) 320, (*) 360 and (●) 400. Fig. 9 Effect of total metal loading of catalyst on gas product distribution. Reaction conditions: 0.2g of Cu80ZnO20-CNTs catalyst, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric flow rate of mixed water and methanol liquid=7cm3/h, molar ratio of water to methanol in feed=1.5, temperature 320°C, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min: (■) CH3OH conversion, (□) H2 concentration, (▴) CO concentration and (●) CO2 concentration. Fig. 10 Effect of Cu in total metal loading of catalyst on hydrogen production. Reaction conditions: 0.2g of 23wt% Cu/ZnO-CNTs catalyst, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric rate of mixed liquid reactant of water and methanol=7cm3/h, the reactant molar ratio of water/methanol=1.5, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min; temperature (°C): (♦) 200, (■) 240, (▴) 280, (×) 320 and (*) 360. Fig. 11 Effect of Cu in total metal loading of catalyst on hydrogen yield and CO concentration. Reaction condition: 0.2g of 23wt% Cu/ZnO-CNTs catalyst, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric rate of mixed liquid reactant of water and methanol=7cm3/h, the reactant molar ratio of water/methanol=1.5, temperature 320°C, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min: (□) yield of hydrogen and (■) CO concentration. Table 1 Effect of basic solution and ethanol on 15wt% Cu/CNTs NaOH solution (cm3) Ethanol (cm3) Cracking temperature of nano-tubes (°C) Cu loading (wt%) Cu particle size (nm) Nature of Cu/CNT from TEM analysis 28 0 439.5 22.18 ∼500 Cu aggregates not adsorbed on CNT 21 7 454.0 15.53 ∼10 Good Cu particle dispersion and adsorption on CNTs 14 14 465.0 13.05 ∼20 Cu aggregation around the CNTs 7 21 462.9 10.25 ∼50 Larger Cu particles adsorbed on CNTs 0 28 510.3 2.56 – No Cu particles observed around CNTs Pre-treatment condition of CNT: 27.7cm3 of 0.01M Cu(NO3)2·3H2O solution, molar ratio (formaldehyde/copper nitrate)=10/1, 37% of formaldehyde. Table 2 Effect relative loading of 23wt% Cu n ZnO(100−n)/CNTs on cracking temperature of CNTs n Residual percentage of samples (wt%) Real loading of Cu and ZnO (wt%) Cracking temperatures (°C) 80 27.44 24.21 523.76 70 26.13 23.30 519.89 60 26.03 23.64 527.33 40 23.06 21.61 523.97 20 22.78 22.06 534.04 Pre-treatment condition of CNT: 27.7cm3 of 0.01M Cu(NO3)2·3H2O solution, molar ratio (formaldehyde/copper nitrate)=10/1, 37% of formaldehyde. Table 3 Effect of metal loading of Cu80ZnO20/CNTs on steam reforming of methanol Metal loading (wt%) H2 yield at 320°C (%) Maximum H2 yield (%) CO2 selectivity (maximum/minimum, mol%) Maximum CO concentration (mol%) 35 69.3 97.1 98.6/83.2 4.18 30 85.9 97.1 99.7/91.5 2.29 26 84.1 100 94.7/80.7 3.71 23 83.9 100 99.1/94.7 1.21 17 66.9 85.2 98.4/91.8 2.23 Reaction conditions: 0.2g of catalyst, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric flow rate of mixed water and methanol liquid=7cm3/h, molar ratio of water to methanol=1.5, temperature 200–400°C, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min. Table 4 Effect relative loading of 23wt% Cu n ZnO(100−n)/CNTs on steam reforming of methanol n H2 yield at 320°C (%) Maximum H2 production rate (mmol/skgcat) CO2 selectivity (maximum/minimum, mol%) Maximum CO concentration (mol%) 100 51.1 305.3 92.9/82.1 4.08 90 71.5 344.9 95.3/84.2 4.02 80 72.8 426.7 99.1/94.7 1.21 70 75.0 404.3 99.3/97.3 0.73 60 74.5 393.1 98.9/92.9 1.86 40 76.7 404.9 98.7/95.7 1.05 20 71.2 328.1 95.2/92.7 1.14 Reaction conditions: 0.2g of catalyst, WHSV=30.5h−1, volumetric flow rate of mixed water and methanol liquid=7cm3/h, molar ratio of water to methanol=1.5, temperature 200–400°C, volumetric rate of carrier gas (nitrogen)=80cm3/min. Preparation and activity of Cu/ZnO-CNTs nano-catalyst on steam reforming of methanol Hung-Ming Yang ⁎ Ping-Heng Liao Department of Chemical Engineering, National Chung Hsing University, 250 Kuo-kuang Road, Taichung 402, Taiwan, ROC ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +886 4 22840510x609; fax: +886 4 22854734. Graphical abstract A novel Cu/ZnO-CNTs (carbon nano-tubes) nano-catalyst was prepared by chemical reduction and wet impregnation method, and was applied to catalyze the steam reforming reaction of methanol. CH3OH+H2O⇌CO2 +3H2 XRD analysis of 23wt% Cu/ZnO-CNTs catalysts; (▾) CNT, (▿) CuO, (♦) ZnO, (●) Cu. A novel Cu/ZnO-CNTs (carbon nano-tubes) nano-catalyst was prepared by a chemical reduction and wet impregnation method, and was applied to catalyze the steam reforming reaction of methanol. If one uses CNT as the support, the CNTs should be pre-treated by nitric acid and sulfuric acid at 60°C for 24h to create defects on its surface; the hydrophilicity of CNTs was improved by adding a suitable amount of ethanol. The catalysts were characterized by TEM, XRD, FTIR and TGA. A good dispersion of Cu nano-particles on the surface of CNTs with particle size about 10nm is identified by TEM analysis. Using 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs as the catalyst, we obtained the hydrogen yield for steam reforming of methanol of 83% at 280°C and near 100% at temperatures higher than 320°C with 1.5 of molar ratio of water to methanol. The higher hydrogen production (larger than 400mmol/(skgcat)), higher selectivity of CO2 and lower CO concentration were also observed. Keywords Carbon nano-tubes Nano-catalyst Chemical reduction method Methanol steam reforming 1 Introduction Carbon nano-tubes (CNTs) are new and interesting materials because of their many special properties, such as high ratio of length/diameter, unique conductivity, strength and flexibility [1]. Due to the capability of adsorbing useful materials on CNT, the applications of CNT in catalysis have tremendously increased. Carbon nano-tubes-supported catalysts can be used as electrodes in lithium-ion batteries [2], and as materials for hydrogen storage [3,4]. Liu et al. [5] used Ni/CNTs as catalysts to synthesize carbon nano-tubes that had a high quality and purity. They showed that carbon nano-tubes can be a good material as catalyst support, and thus the investigations for effective impregnating metal/metal oxide onto the surface of CNTs are important. For example, copper and copper oxide can be supported on carbon nano-tubes by an electroless plating method. Ang et al. [6] showed that metals could be coated on carbon nano-tubes in a single step of activation, yielding a layer of copper or nickel on the surface of nano-tubes, and the extent of metal decoration was dependent on the age of the sensitizing solution via a two-step sensitization-activation approach. Wu et al. [7] also used this method to prepare CuO on carbon nano-tubes. They found that CuO on nano-tubes could reversibly store 268mAh Li/g. Most of carbon nano-tubes catalysts were prepared by this method, from which metals would be coated as a layer on the nano-tubes surface; here, the amount of metal supported could not be easily controlled. In addition, the pre-treatment of CNT cannot be ignored in preparing catalysts, because pre-treatment formed the functional groups on nano-tubes surface [8]. Hence, some more effective methods for accurately loading the desired metals on CNTs are required. Hydrogen is a very important component for fuel cell, and is its raw material. Three methods of producing hydrogen from methanol are partial oxidation, decomposition and steam reforming; among these, partial oxidation and steam reforming might be more attractive to produce hydrogen. Wang et al. [9] and Alejo et al. [10] utilized Cu-based catalysts containing a binary or ternary metal to catalyze the partial oxidation of methanol. They obtained the high methanol conversion and hydrogen selectivity by using Cu60Cr40 catalysts as compared to other binary catalysts and catalysts that contain Zn promoter for improving the activity and stability. The hydrogen-rich product gas produced from steam reforming of methanol is another route that can feed fuel cells, using Cu-based catalysts in the presence of Zn to enhance the catalytic activity and stability [11]. Peppley et al. [12] improved the reaction with Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 catalysts and described the reaction network for modeling the process of methanol steaming reforming in order to account for the range of product compositions observed. In this study, carbon nano-tubes were used as the catalyst support; they were pre-treated with acids and by a chemical reduction method, instead of by an electroless plating method, to prepare Cu/ZnO-CNTs. The amount of metal and the copper cluster sizes would be controlled. The CNT-supported catalyst was then used to catalyze the methanol steam-reforming reaction. The efficiency of catalysts, the effects of metal loading, the relative amounts of Cu to ZnO in catalyst, and the molar ratio of reactants were all discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The commercial multi-walled carbon nano-tubes with tube diameters of about 30–60nm were used. The preparation of Cu/ZnO-CNTs catalysts includes three steps. First, the chemical pre-treatment of carbon nano-tubes is required. A definite amount of carbon nano-tubes was introduced into 40cm3 of nitric acid and sulfuric acid (3:1 in volume) solution, then 10cm3 of ethanol were dropped into the solution slowly, and the solution was agitated in a shaker at 70°C and 150rpm for 24h. The second step is the supporting of copper on carbon nano-tubes by a chemical reduction process. 0.01M of copper nitrate aqueous solution and ethanol were mixed in equal amounts with the solution of 0.01N of basic solution (pH 12), which was prepared by NaOH and Na2CO3 in a volume ratio of 3. The desired amount of carbon nano-tubes after chemical pre-treatment was put into the prescribed aqueous solution in an ultrasonic bath to react for 2h with a solution of 37% formaldehyde (10/1 of formaldehyde and copper nitrate in molar ratio), which was dropped into the solution slowly. After the chemical reduction reaction, the solids were separated from the solution using a centrifuge and washed with deionized water until a pH value around 7 for the washed water was attained. The third step was to support zinc oxide on carbon nano-tubes by wet impregnation. The desired amounts of zinc acetate dehydrate and the copper-supported carbon nano-tubes were agitated in an ultrasonic bath of 60cm3 of deionized water with the addition of 10cm3 of 1N NaOH and 10cm3 of ethanol in turn for 1h. The solid samples were separated with centrifuging and dried at 105°C for 4h. The solid samples were then calcined at 350°C for 2h, and reduced with 15cm3/min of hydrogen and 80cm3/min of nitrogen at 260°C for 30min to obtain the nano-catalyst Cu/ZnO-CNTs. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The crystal phase present in catalysts was determined by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) operating with 40kV of voltage and 30mA of tube current to obtain Cu Kα radiation (wavelength=1.54056Å) and with 2θ scanning from 20° to 80°; the phase identification was performed using the reference database (JCPDS-files). The metal particle size and distribution in catalysts were observed with an Analytical Electron Microscope (JEOL JEM-1200CX II), for which the catalyst sample was grinded and dispersed in isopropyl alcohol in an ultrasonic bath for 15min, and then coated on a carbon-coated copper screen. After evaporation of alcohol, the sample was analyzed with TEM. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was applied to determine the true metal loading and to analyze the thermal properties of supported carbon nano-tubes. The rate of temperature increase was 10°C/min to heat from 100 to 900°C with input air. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was used to detect the functional groups on the surface of CNTs. Spectra obtained in a FTIR spectrometer were corrected for slope and baseline and then expanded in adsorbance. 2.3 Reactor system An isothermal fixed-bed tubular reactor packed with 0.2g of Cu/ZnO-CNTs catalyst was used to perform the steam reforming of methanol. The reactor consisted of a 3.5cm length of stainless steel pipe with a diameter of 1/4in., for which two thermocouples were set at the entrance and exit of reactor to measure the reaction temperature. The liquid reactants, water and methanol with the desired molar ratio were well mixed in an ultrasonic bath for 1h, and preheated at 60°C, then allowed to continuously feed to the reactor at the desired flow rate. For ensuring the gas flow within the reactor system, we kept all pipes above 120°C. The reaction was carried out at a temperature in the range of 200–400°C with the flow rate of nitrogen dilution gas at 80cm3/min and at atmospheric pressure. The gas stream leaving the reactor was analyzed online by gas chromatography with TCD using a packed column with argon as carrier gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effect of preparing condition and catalysts characterization Carbon nano-tubes are a kind of hydrophobic material [13], and it is difficult to adsorb metal on their surfaces. In order to support metals effectively, the surfaces of CNT should have defects to form functional groups, such as CO, COOH and OH. Concentrated acids can be used to introduce functional groups on the surfaces of carbonaceous materials [14]. Therefore, CNTs were pre-treated with concentrated nitric and sulfuric acids to effectively support active metals and to remove impurities on the surface. The nature of the surface functional groups was investigated by FTIR spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 1 . Whether CNTs was pre-treated with acids or not, the peak at 1630cm−1 was present due to contaminating water. Before the chemical pre-treatment, the CNT samples had two obvious peaks at 1550 and 1440cm−1. The peak at 1550cm−1 was observed from carbon black, and the other at 1440cm−1 was connected with the OH bending deformation in carboxylic acids and phenolic groups. The chemical pre-treatment can make CO and OH functional groups present a peak of 1720cm−1, which was connected with CO stretching of carboxylic acids, larger lactones or other carbonyls. In addition, the higher peak at 1440cm−1 remained present in the spectra because of a larger amount of OH bending functional groups, while the peak at 1550cm−1 was observed lower, confirming that chemical pre-treatment could remove surface impurities including surplus carbon black. The chemical pre-treatment cannot only make CNTs form functional groups but can also enhance the thermal property of CNT; the results can be analyzed by TGA. From Fig. 2 , we see that the cracking temperature of commercial CNTs was 570°C without pre-treatment and with the impurities about 3–5%, but the cracking temperature with pre-treatment was raised to 645°C due to the elimination of impurities. By TGA analysis, the amount of metal loading on CNTs can also be estimated from the residual wt% of samples, implying that the metal oxide is supported on CNTs. Moreover, CNT is hydrophobic enough to have a low adsorption affinity in polar solvents, such as in water and aqueous metallic solutions. In preparing 15wt% Cu on CNTs without chemical pre-treatment, we observed that only less than 10wt% Cu was actually loaded, as shown in Fig. 2; with chemical pre-treatment, the true loading of Cu was accordingly about 15wt%. The introduction of functional groups reduces the hydrophobicity of CNTs, resulting in an enhanced affinity for metal precursors to the surfaces. Since CNT is a type of hydrophobic material, it is difficult to effectively contact with the more polar aqueous solution containing Cu precursor. If one wants to successfully load Cu on CNTs, the polarity of the aqueous solution should be decreased and the hydrophilicity of CNTs should be increased. By the addition of ethanol, the polarity of the aqueous solution is reduced; furthermore, with the pre-treatment of CNTs by acids, as described in Section 2, the surface of CNTs can be made to form acidic functional groups to increase the hydrophilicity. Thus, a suitable amount of ethanol can be employed to promote dispersing copper particles for contacting with CNT surfaces more easily. The effects of amounts of ethanol and basic solution on Cu supported on CNTs are shown in Table 1 . The cracking temperatures of supported CNTs for different amounts of ethanol added were between 430 and 465°C. The loading amount and particle size of Cu were affected obviously by the addition of ethanol. As the volumetric ratio of basic solution to ethanol was 3, the loading amount of copper was about 15wt%, indicating that the hydrophobicity of CNT was diminished at this volumetric ratio and a higher Cu dispersion was possible. Higher or lower ratios of basic solution to ethanol led to Cu particle aggregation or less ability of adsorption on the CNT surface. TEM analysis was used to observe the dispersion and size of copper particles. Without addition of ethanol, the Cu particles had a larger size of about 500nm with a higher aggregation, and were not adsorbed on the surface of CNT, while the smaller particle sizes were observed for added ethanol. The results by TGA can also be confirmed by TEM analysis to illustrate that a better dispersion and effective adsorption of Cu particles on the CNT surface can be achieved. Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of Cu supported on CNT with or without pre-treatment. In Fig. 3(b) without the acid pre-treatment, although most smaller Cu particles were adsorbed on the surface with about 20–30nm, but they exhibited a serious Cu aggregation and a lower dispersion due to the lack of functional groups on the surface and a higher hydrophobocity of CNTs. As seen in Fig. 3(a), without the addition of ethanol, Cu particles had sizes about 500nm and were not adsorbed on CNTs; besides, there were some other impure substances present. As seen in Fig. 3(c), with pre-treatment and the addition of suitable ethanol, the Cu particles were about 10–20nm and adsorbed on CNTs successfully, exhibiting more introduction of functional groups and less hydrophobicity of CNTs. The Cu metal supported on CNTs were prepared by the above methods. For preparing 23wt% Cu/ZnO-CNTs with different ratios of Cu and ZnO, the subsequent wet impregnation was applied. The thermal properties and true metal loading in catalysts are listed in Table 2 , showing the compositions of catalysts contained 23wt% of metal with different weight ratios of Cu and ZnO; the true loadings of total metals were estimated from residual weight% of samples. The data shows the true loadings of total metals to be about 21–24wt%; such percentages are close to the amounts of metals supported, and the deviations are less than 2wt%. The catalysts exhibited the cracking temperatures of supported CNTs at about 520–535°C, showing that the metal loading led to the cracking temperature decrease of about 120°C, compared with the cracking temperature of 645°C for the pure commercial CNTs. Fig. 4 shows the XRD pattern for catalyst identification. The peaks of CNT were 26° and 42°, and the peaks of 43° and 50° were associated with Cu, while ZnO had peaks of 31°, 34° and 36° in XRD pattern. The samples also showed the peaks of CuO at 35° and 38°, because the Cu nanoparticles had a higher activity to react with oxygen in air and were observed in XRD patterns. The intensities of peaks increased with increasing the amount of Cu or ZnO. 3.2 Steam reforming reaction of methanol The steam reforming reaction of methanol can produce hydrogen for fuel cells. In our work, we used the nano-catalyst Cu/ZnO-CNTs to catalyze the reaction in a fixed-bed reactor. The reaction conditions were set at 0.2g of catalysts, 30.5h−1 of WHSV, 7cm3/min of volumetric flow rate of liquid reactants of mixed water and methanol, 1.5 of molar ratio of water to methanol, and the temperatures at 200–400°C with 80cm3/min of the dilution gas nitrogen. Since the cracking temperature of the catalyst was above 500°C, the reaction temperatures were all set at below 400°C to avoid catalyst cracking. Fig. 5 shows the concentrations of methanol, hydrogen and carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide in exit gas as a function of temperature. The conversion of methanol was estimated by total productions of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide in exit gas. The results show that the amount of hydrogen increased with increasing reaction temperature, and that the catalytic activity of 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs was greatly raised as the temperature was greater than 240°C. Methanol mostly converted to hydrogen, carbon dioxide and a little carbon monoxide when the temperature was greater than 280°C. The Cu-based catalysts caused the methanol steam reforming reaction to be much faster than methanol decomposition; however, methanol decomposition might occur in a higher temperature due to a higher heat provided. Furthermore, a high selectivity of carbon dioxide exhibited that the main reaction was steam reforming with a very minor reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS) to produce carbon monoxide. The high activity and high selectivity of carbon dioxide were observed using 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNT as catalyst. The effects of the molar ratio of water to methanol on hydrogen production at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 6 . A similar tendency at each molar ratio was observed, implying an optimal condition to produce hydrogen. When the reaction temperature was below 240°C, a higher hydrogen production was obtained at a molar ratio of 3, but a higher hydrogen production occurred at 1.5 above 280°C. When the molar ratio of water to methanol was increased, more water led the optimal hydrogen production condition to shift from 1.3 to 1.5. Nevertheless, an even higher molar ratio than 1.5 of water to methanol restrained the production of hydrogen. Moreover, a higher amount of methanol than water at 0.5 of molar ratio would produce more hydrogen due to much more methanol reacting with water. Fig. 7 shows the selectivity of carbon dioxide. The decrease of selectivity of carbon dioxide followed the increase of temperature. The selectivity's were all above 90%, even though the molar ratio of water to methanol was at 0.8 or 0.5. These results agree with the results shown in Fig. 6. In addition, with the Cu-based catalyst, a lower molar ratio of water to methanol resulted in a higher amount of carbon monoxide because of the faster reverse water-gas shift reaction of CO2 and H2, which are formed from the methanol steam reforming reaction. The obvious tendency exhibited was that the selectivity of carbon dioxide decreased intensely at molar ratios of 0.8 and 0.5, compared with other ratios larger than 1. Fig. 8 shows the effect of total metal loading in catalyst on hydrogen production. The results indicate that an optimal total metal loading at each temperature for Cu80ZnO20-CNTs catalysts exists. At 280°C, the catalyst 30wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs had the highest activity, and the activity of catalyst first increased with increasing the total metal loading, and then decreased when the loading was at 35wt%. This is because a higher content of metal would destroy the structure of supported CNTs by cracking, or by a serious aggregation of metal. At a temperature above 280°C, the highest activity of catalyst Cu80ZnO20-CNTs gradually shifted from 30 to 23wt% with the increase of temperature. A higher temperature might lead to an easier cracking of supported carbon nano-tubes. The concentrations of CO, CO2 and H2 at 320°C are shown in Fig. 9 . At a low temperature, the higher metal loading in catalyst enhanced the activity of catalyst; as a result, the reaction proceeded in the route of methanol steam reforming reaction more easily. Nevertheless, at a high temperature the reactions would proceed by both methanol steam reforming and RWGS routes. Hence, the concentration of carbon monoxide increased with increasing metal content while the concentration of carbon dioxide decreased, because the reactivity of RWGS reaction increased with increasing metal content. Consequently, the results also confirmed the results in Fig. 8, showing that the highest activity of catalyst shifted to 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs. The results for the effect of total metal loading are summarized in Table 3 . The yield of hydrogen reached nearly 100%, except using 17wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs catalyst, and the selectivity of carbon dioxide and the concentration of carbon monoxide exhibited between 80.7–99.7% and 1.21–4.18%. Fig. 10 shows the effect of the relative ratio of Cu and ZnO for 23wt% Cu/ZnO-CNTs. The catalysts Cu70ZnO30-CNTs and Cu80ZnO20-CNTs showed the highest activity below and above 280°C. A lower and higher content of Cu both had a low activity in steam reforming reaction. The hydrogen production increased with an increase of Cu content, but decreased with Cu content larger than 70% below 280°C, and decreased with Cu content larger than 80% above 280°C. The difference of hydrogen production between the highest and the lowest activity was around 150mmol/(skgcat). The Cu content between 40 and 80% showed the same activity to produce high hydrogen production greater than 350mmol/(skgcat). The suitable content of ZnO promoted the activity of catalysts and decreased the production of monoxide; the results are shown in Fig. 11 . When the content of ZnO was lower than 20%, the concentration of CO increased significantly because of more and more methanol decomposition. The content of ZnO greater than 20% led the concentration of carbon monoxide less than 1mol%, but this increased to 4mol% with the ZnO content smaller than 20%. The results of the effect of Cu/ZnO relative weight ratio are summarized in Table 4 . The selectivity of CO2 and concentration of CO were between 82 and 99.3% and 0.73 and 4.08%. A ZnO content less than 10% caused a lower hydrogen production and selectivity with more carbon monoxide produced. 4 Conclusion In this study, we successfully prepared the novel Cu/ZnO-CNTs nano-catalysts by using a chemical reduction and wet impregnation method, instead of an electroless plating method. The copper nano-particles with the size of 10–20nm in diameter were achieved and supported on carbon nano-tubes with good dispersion. The chemical pre-treatment promoted formation of functional groups on the surfaces of carbon nano-tubes. The necessary functional groups on the surface of supports and a suitable addition of ethanol improve the hydrophilicity of carbon nano-tubes to enhance the homogenous dispersion of metal particles. The Cu/ZnO-CNTs nano-catalyst caused a high activity and selectivity of carbon dioxide in methanol steam reforming reaction at 200–400°C. The highest activity was shifted from 30 to 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs with an increase of temperature. The higher content of copper in catalyst had a higher activity, but the catalysts with Cu contents of 90 and 100% had a lower activity, and the addition of ZnO increased the selectivity of CO2. coredata.dc:description: A novel Cu/ZnO-CNTs (carbon nano-tubes) nano-catalyst was prepared by a chemical reduction and wet impregnation method, and was applied to catalyze the steam reforming reaction of methanol. If one uses CNT as the support, the CNTs should be pre-treated by nitric acid and sulfuric acid at 60°C for 24h to create defects on its surface; the hydrophilicity of CNTs was improved by adding a suitable amount of ethanol. The catalysts were characterized by TEM, XRD, FTIR and TGA. A good dispersion of Cu nano-particles on the surface of CNTs with particle size about 10nm is identified by TEM analysis. Using 23wt% Cu80ZnO20-CNTs as the catalyst, we obtained the hydrogen yield for steam reforming of methanol of 83% at 280°C and near 100% at temperatures higher than 320°C with 1.5 of molar ratio of water to methanol. The higher hydrogen production (larger than 400mmol/(skgcat)), higher selectivity of CO2 and lower CO concentration were also observed.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation and activity of Cu/ZnO-CNTs nano-catalyst on steam reforming of methanol
